newsitem.title: USA: Plane evacuated in New York after fire, six hurt.
newsitem.headline: Plane evacuated in New York after fire, six hurt.

text.p: A fire broke out in the tail of a Continental Airlines plane at La Guardia airport on Thursday, forcing passengers to evacuate by chute onto the runway, officials said.

Six passengers on Cleveland-bound Flight 1993 were injured, a spokeswoman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which manages the region's major airports, said. All the injuries were minor and occurred during evacuation.

"There was a fire in the tail cone that was quickly extinguished by the Port Authority police rescue team," spokeswoman Gwen Williams said. "The fire broke out while the aircraft was on the taxiway at 9:42 this morning, it hadn't taken off."
Continental Airlines said the pilot also activated the fire extinguishers on both engines of the MD-80 plane.

Airline spokeswoman Sarah Anthony said the fire began after a "false start" in the no. 2 engine that was similar to a car backfiring. She said the 89 passengers and 5 crew were evacuated on two chutes and were being accommodated on other flights.

In an incident Thursday at Stewart International Airport in Newburgh, New York, officials said a DC-10 plane owned by FedEx Corporation was engulfed by flames after making an emergency landing. The three people on board were unharmed.
